channel.title: Collecting Text/Color data
channel.description:
Hey guys, with that "459 lookalike engine" out, and 508+ servers having a better text engine, I wanted to make a little app to help with colors and such.
But I can't do this alone. I don't know all the possible variables and stuff. I've only got my 317 server with a partial 459 text engine in it.
I know what the strikethrough looks like, I know what the transparency looks like (except if you go above 100, that outputs some whack colors). I kind of know what col/shad do. (essentially they're just color techniques using the decimal system). and I know a few of the @dbl@ things.
What I need from you: As much data as possible on text engines in RSPS's. I know there's more than above (I'm not adding the <img=X> because that is strictly server based).
Format: [code] Revision: Info: Other: [/code] Example: [hr] Revision: 317 (loading higher data) Info: <col=int>TextHere</col> outputs text in decimal based colors. Other: Is on 317 servers with new text engines implemented.
Sorry if I confused you.

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:24, topic:522468”]not many different people help in the development of client data. so it’s not too ‘user dependent’ it only varies sometimes.

but still. there’s not really much you can add besides the and coloring. if you seriously want to add shortcuts for alt codes, go ahead. but none of it is needed and i doubt jagex did it in any of their clients.[/quote]
Nah, Jagex wouldn’t put the alt codes in. But they aren’t restricted. Meaning you can do ALT+0 or what ever and it shows in game.

Read full topic

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:22, topic:522468”]deathlypbpz and trisidiax are servers. they have nothing to do with the client.

there’s quite a few ‘base clients’ out there, but all you really need to know is revision. refacoring/naming is all up to the user. content is per revision.

regardless of upgrading the text engine itself, it will all hold the same data (the color codes wont change depending on the revision)

however, if you’re referring to the simple things like strikethrough, italics, bold, underline, etc. those can be added to any revision.

also note, the data used per revision depend on the person who adds the content (unless it’s per jagex)[/quote]

The 459-lookalike I threw in my client (had to do it like 15 times because fuck my client) uses strikethrough and all that. But it also uses key “codes” like if you type it would print: ©
and some others. I don’t know if I could expect that in others.

My idea behind this post would be to get the ‘general’ behind it, because yes, as you stated, it’s user dependent.

Read full topic

also note, the data used per revision depend on the person who adds the content (unless it’s per jagex)

item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:17, topic:522468”]your idea of collecting the data is useless because “my client may not be the same as everyone elses” therefore, the data will not be added.

anyone can add more colors to @col@ and color: to the chat packet. the only data that needs to be ‘gathered’ would be the color codes, and there are plentiful resources on the web[/quote]
You’re forgetting that 90% of what is/has been released runs on the same clients (nowadays).
That being DeathlyPvpz
TrisidiaX
and a couple others.
Granted that’s only 317. I’m doubting that 600+, 700+, or even 508+ run using the same text engine, even with the 459 look a like. That’s essentially the point here. To get all the text/color data possible.

Read full topic

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:19, topic:522468”]you’re slightly confusing yourself.

#ffffff is hexadecimal
i believe it converts to 16777215 in decimal

255,255,255 is rgb values.

and the <,> are generally used with decimal color integers, but i’ve seen few clients use hexadecimal and some even use both.[/quote]
Yeah, yeah…I was almost correct. I am still right about the hexadecimal. I was only referring to the tags for the colors. I wont go through an argument I am entirely wrong about.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_

and the <,> are generally used with decimal color integers, but i’ve seen few clients use hexadecimal and some even use both.

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

Vain_:

@wildskiller, the color codes are decimal, not hexadecimal (however both are used in the client)

The default color values are decimal, but what you need inside of the diamond parameters are hexadecimal. This is what I’ve been referring to the whole damn time.

#FFFFFF --> Hexadecimal color code
255 255 255 --> Decimal color code

I NEVER said that colors are only hexadecimal. I’ve been talking about what you are putting inside of the diamond parameters (or tags).

Read full topic

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

@wildskiller, the color codes are decimal, not hexadecimal (however both are used in the client)

your idea of collecting the data is useless because “my client may not be the same as everyone elses” therefore, the data will not be added.

anyone can add more colors to @col@ and color: to the chat packet. the only data that needs to be ‘gathered’ would be the color codes, and there are plentiful resources on the web

Read full topic

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:15, topic:522468”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=640970.msg4324828#msg4324828 date=1372717569]

It would’ve been simpler to say <col=COLOR_HEX_CODE>Text here. There wouldn’t have been any confusion then.

There’s no hex codes used, it’s Decimal.

Hexadecimal*, whatever.

DECIMAL. Smart ass.
[/quote]
Decimals contain a DOT in the number. Hexadecimals can contain LETTERS and are just based on 16 symbols.[/quote]
Oh really?

Noun 1. decimal notation - any notation that uses 10 different characters (usually the digits 0 to 9)
and I mean. Then there's this: http://www.mathsisfun.com/hexadecimal-decimal-colors.html

I know what hexadecimal is.
It’s a base 16. 10-16 being letters a-f…

Read full topic

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Arcik:

Why don’t you look through the client and find out?

Because my client won’t be the same as everyones. Nor is it. I’m trying to get as much data as possible.
I’ve only got the standard runescape text colors (things like purple: cyan: flash1:), the 459 look-a-like system () and the typical 317 data (@dbl@ @red@). But I’m sure there’s more. Hex, I haven’t really seen used in RSPS, text wise, but if it is (Aside from setting interface text colors via RSInterface.java), I’d like to know.
That’s the point of this. I need to know all the various ways colors and text is used.

Read full topic

But I want to know if there’s more than what the standard 317 has, like more than @col@, <col=234325348>, and “purple:”
I’m collecting this data for a specific reason.

item.title: Collecting Text/Color data
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

This would take you about 3 minutes of work sk8r, it’s not hard to find.

private int getColorByName(String s) { if(s.equals("red")) return 0xff0000; if(s.equals("gre")) return 65280; if(s.equals("blu")) return 255; if(s.equals("yel")) return 0xffff00; if(s.equals("cya")) return 65535; if(s.equals("mag")) return 0xff00ff; if(s.equals("whi")) return 0xffffff; if(s.equals("bla")) return 0; if(s.equals("lre")) return 0xff9040; if(s.equals("dre")) return 0x800000; if(s.equals("dbl")) return 128; if(s.equals("or1")) return 0xffb000; if(s.equals("or2")) return 0xff7000; if(s.equals("or3")) return 0xff3000; if(s.equals("gr1")) return 0xc0ff00; if(s.equals("gr2")) return 0x80ff00; if(s.equals("gr3")) return 0x40ff00; if(s.equals("str")) strikeThrough = true; if(s.equals("end")) strikeThrough = false; return -1; }

Read full topic
